F2A3AE2831F44DC2B869ABF451C3565B.description: explain that scientific knowledge and theories develop through hypotheses, the collection of evidence through investigation and the ability to provide explanations (NS2)

8F24F9AE787D402A8869BDFF8901561D.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Nature of Science Emphasis)

AA8D1BA4F71E40A4857EBAFD9B5B418E.description: compare the growth pattern of the human population to that of other species.

28D45949064340368D41513F693043F4.description: describe how factors including space, accumulation of wastes (e.g., salinization of soil), competition, technological innovations, irrigation practices (e.g., Hohokam farmers) and the availability of food impact the size of populations

CCC423F959FF47AD9B76252F29F7FD13.description: compare gradual evolution with punctuated equilibrium

9DB61EF18DD4455DB404D6D51ED2BE45.description: describe evidence for evolution by natural selection; e.g., fossils, biogeography, embryology, homologous and vestigial structures, biochemical research

C71F694D89AB43038AFCBA5FADF86675.description: describe evidence for evolution by natural selection; e.g., fossils, biogeography, embryology, homologous and vestigial structures, biochemical research

6DCF330382924D7DA85F911B02B2B0CC.description: describe the adaptation of species over time due to variation in a population, population size and environmental change; e.g., bacterial resistance to antibiotics, giraffe neck length, gazelle speed

93D916AD5E144F47A37F82F5879CEF51.description: describe mutation as the principal cause for variation of genes in species and populations, identify the role of sexual reproduction in generating variability among individuals and describe the forces that drive evolution

C7B7AE44F97F4C09A75BAED25A923DE8.description: Students will analyze and describe the adaptation of organisms to their environments, factors limiting natural populations, and evolutionary change in an ecological context.

ECD7312063CE4ADA8AAC7CF18563B95A.description: explain that science and technology are developed to meet societal needs and expand human capabilities

B11EFADF1294460E98C00409C715B0BC.description: explain that science and technology have both intended and unintended consequences for humans and the environment

BE18993C55E142F9941F520638F9AC43.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

9E6CBB46420046AEA7CD97CED4E519C2.description: explain why population size and biomass are both directly related to the trophic level of the species and explain how trophic levels can be described in terms of pyramids of numbers, biomass or energy.

B347B0E5E57F45219F94DC1116BF3CF7.description: analyze and describe how energy flows in an ecosystem, using the concepts of conservation of energy (second law of thermodynamics); energy input and output through trophic levels, food webs, chains and pyramids; and specific examples of autotrophs and heterotrophs

BD2BCF8AE7E54F758F1D5AF261AF66E6.description: describe artificial and natural factors that affect the biogeochemical cycles

CFD6DF44EF6A4A9FB57309956CDF37A9.description: outline the biogeochemical cycles of nitrogen, carbon, oxygen and water and, in general terms, describe their interconnectedness, building on knowledge of the hydrologic cycle from Science 10, Unit D

994E23B89CC14E279B742E7278B77FD9.description: Students will analyze and investigate the cycling of matter and the flow of energy through the biosphere and ecosystems as well as the interrelationship of society and the environment.

414F94236F424A3E97A49BA375654772.description: describe how society provides direction for scientific and technological development

AB9538F7B24F4744ABFA759E1DFEB3E9.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Social and Environmental Contexts Emphasis)

6D34F92D3E234D51953A82347818F413.description: describe the effects of introducing a new species into, or largely removing an established species from, an environment; e.g., zebra mussel, carp and the Eurasian milfoil in Canada's lakes, purple loosestrife in Alberta, the horse or the buffalo in the plains region of Alberta.

52DFA5A7642542E4A958218CACCC6283.description: describe the potential impact of habitat destruction on an ecosystem

9ABDA7B968F14709A7458CA035931BC5.description: differentiate between primary and secondary succession in a specific aquatic and a specific terrestrial ecosystem, e.g., pond, river, lake, forest, parkland, and compare natural and artificial means to initiate secondary succession in an ecosystem, e.g., reforestation or regrowth after a forest fire, flood or other natural disaster, strip mining, clearcutting, controlled burns by some Aboriginal groups promoting grassland biome regeneration

19F183BFD8094DF2B2967AACE0598DF6.description: describe the key stages of primary succession in a specific ecosystem and the nature of its climax community; e.g., spruce bog, sand dune, pond, prairie

07C86D6A5C5A4BFCAA495EE4E231196E.description: investigate and analyze an aquatic or a terrestrial local ecosystem, distinguish between biotic and abiotic factors, describe how these factors affect population size

F2095B996F254E4B879AD45357825276.description: Students will analyze ecosystems and ecological succession in the local area and describe the relationships and interactions among subsystems and components.

32E138DAA7874CFFB095B2BE3C944812.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Nature of Science Emphasis)

851A35DA8E184225A99B39717EB9F9CD.description: explain, in general terms, how changes to Earth's climate and how mass extinctions could be caused by changes or variation in the following: Earth's orbit around the sun, the inclination of Earth's axis, solar energy output, Earth's geography due to crustal movement, volcanic activity, ocean currents, atmospheric composition or asteroid impact.

1CB9F94E1254489B8ABB5F1F9193A373.description: explain how ice cores from polar icecaps provide evidence of warming and cooling in the past hundred thousand years

5B277E08C71749C782222DD01FD5871A.description: describe the geologic evidence for repeated glaciation over large areas of Canada and in their local area;e.g., the Cypress Hills, gold deposits in the Yukon, topography, drainage patterns, erratics, U-shaped valleys

A73F21F9AD5642C597A7B959F4899F2A.description: Students will analyze the evidence of, and assess the explanations for, natural variations in Earth's climate over the last two million years.

88972B56C65841058299B6A8F0D5BD1A.description: explain why oxygen became a significant component of Earth's atmosphere after the evolution of plants and chlorophyll.

D4F11972C8264B68B91FFA2FE174023F.description: describe, in general terms, the major characteristics and life forms of the four eras: Precambrian, Paleozoic, Mesozoic and Cenozoic

0EF934CC1B474C8B9EE74281532F6AA0.description: explain how sedimentary rock layers along with fossils can provide evidence of chronology, paleoclimate, evolution and mass extinctions; e.g., index and transitional fossils, fossils of reptiles and certain types of plants usually indicate a warm, tropical climate

FA2C8D972DCA4768BA8A358BC1D06C12.description: describe common types of fossilization, i.e., actual remains, molds or imprints, tracks, trails or burrows, as direct evidence of evolution and describe the significance of the fossil record in Canada's Burgess Shale

CC2E19BF42014DFE94C9FF1705F2818F.description: explain how knowledge of radioisotopes, radioactive decay and half-lives are used to estimate the age of minerals and fossils

5E1CF96AE1B249A4A51818298605ACDB.description: Students will will analyze and assess the evidence provided by the fossil record of change in the environment and life forms over a period of 3.5 billion years.

892A80E89831499BA656F4DFAB618C93.description: explain how convection of molten material provides the driving force of plate tectonics, and explain the tentativeness of the explanation that radioactive decay is the source of geothermal energy for plate tectonics.

9A86491C0F2F45DB96B5B989B4AFC158.description: list and describe the evidence that supports the theory of plate tectonics; i.e., location of volcanoes and earthquakes, ocean floor spreading, mountain ranges, age of sediments, paleomagnetism

CCF5E45226374923969AC629A216C592.description: identify and describe the layers of Earth (i.e., lithosphere, asthenosphere, mesosphere, outer core and inner core) as classified by the physical properties of density, rigidity and thickness

6BBB91DA97C74A73B8FD70196C8DA1DD.description: explain how seismic waves are used to better understand the internal structure of Earth

B8366FBC779F40F2B83270BABD7B3905.description: identify primary and secondary seismic waves (P- and S-waves, respectively) and longitudinal and transverse surface waves on the basis of vibration and direction of propagation and potential for destruction

69F921EC111949F8909FE5F9B39C9393.description: describe the relationship between the Richter scale and an earthquake's ground motion and energy

57B5561659B34F16A5DFB825535F76A7.description: describe how energy from earthquakes is transmitted by seismic waves

7E146CB75BDC4A6385EDC169B4A9F4CE.description: Students will analyze and assess the evidence to explain the theory of plate tectonics and the internal structure of Earth.

F8E5B6A8633E4821834B4083765BC6CA.description: describe the challenges in investigating the changes that take place over hundreds of millions of years to Earth's crustal plates, to past climates and to life forms

176E18897F0344368C424AF081F57B80.description: Students will analyze the scientific evidence and explanations for geologic phenomena that occurred long ago or are taking place over a long period of time.

67BE5CD3C0E9453289C42AD5348424EF.description: explain that decisions regarding the application of scientific and technological development involve a variety of perspectives, including social, cultural, environmental, ethical and economic considerations

27C91303796F4AD9B89A0B9F73E63C16.description: explain that the goal of technology is to provide solutions to practical problems

07053EA28897496395980BE8DA4D1D7A.description: Specific Outcomes for Science, Technology and Society (STS) (Science and Technology Emphasis)

0136E0A00D9340B2A13C9C54848162BB.description: relate, quantitatively, potential and kinetic energy to work done.

7ADA5E4B1F724C3F87A10DF7136A06A7.description: apply Newton's third law of motion to explain the interaction between two objects; e.g., collision between two cars

8F3BF70CDDD24523B3CAD76281FF2226.description: apply Newton's second law of motion and use it to relate force, mass and motion; e.g., as an explanation of a whiplash injury from a rear-end collision

04CDAE5635BB4DF791E2BDEE62997B03.description: explain how an unbalanced force causes change in motion and apply Newton's first law of motion to explain an object's state of rest or uniform motion; e.g., movement of passengers in a moving car that accelerates or is coming to a stop

E7C277CB6DF54B2FBDB5EF70FA28DF01.description: define the change in momentum as an impulse (p = mv =Fovet) relate impulse to acceleration and Newton's second law of motion (p/t=ma=F)  and apply the concept of the impulse to explain the functioning of a variety of safety devices; e.g., airbags, collapsible frames, bumpers, seat belts in cars, restraining nets and crash barriers on highways, collapsible steering wheels, padded dashboards, padded helmets, padded goggles, and padded gloves, all of which are designed to increase the stopping time or time of contact by reducing acceleration and, thereby, force

DE8523DEB9124773B483ED684E43787F.description: apply the law of conservation of momentum to one-dimensional collisions and explosions

A340F368B96F4267A4FFF416745D2422.description: define momentum as a vector quantity equal to the product of the mass and velocity of an object(p = mv)

EA93B75DA4154811A895A1DA678CAD3C.description: Students will describe and analyze the law of conservation of momentum for one-dimensional collisions and change in momentum (impulse) to explain how force affects motion.

1C893CD497B24889BEEFF1F2F873DC28.description: work collaboratively in addressing problems and apply the skills and conventions of science in communicating information and ideas and in assessing results

3ABF592B3F934BC8929D5396410EBC9A.description: analyze data and apply mathematical and conceptual models to develop and assess possible solutions,analyze position-time and velocity-time graphs to infer the relationships among displacement, velocity and acceleration, andsolve, quantitatively, one-dimensional uniform motion and uniformly accelerated motion problems usingd=vt+(1/2)at and d=((v+v)/2)t.

FB019C39BD0C45789DF30AD60D07862E.description: compare and contrast displacement in uniform motion and uniformly accelerated motion, using the following relationships:d=vt+(1/2)at andd=((v+v)/2)t.

7C8EF2BC17894128B6B5D00F5B575007.description: define velocity and acceleration asv=d/t anda=v/t respectively

CE3E009136CA49E481A06C7A5ADC169A.description: distinguish between scalar and vector quantities, including distance and displacement, speed and velocity

820A248DCF4C43D1A1D7C52DA9703670.description: Students will describe one-dimensional motion of objects in terms of displacement, time, velocity and acceleration .

82586FF8783B4BF6837D9CF0C016F264.description: identify hydrocarbons as a source of fossil fuels and explain the processes of fractional distillation to refine petroleum and catalytic cracking to produce ethene (ethylene)

B4A5972A263D4889B5C314A1033277CD.description: provide International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) names and structural formulas for simple and noncyclic hydrocarbons in the homologous series of alkanes, alkenes and alkynes that contain up to eight carbon atoms in the parent chain

8B3994A46CEB4DCBA9B20ABC10965C58.description: identify the physical characteristics of hydrocarbons, including trends with respect to melting and boiling points and solubility of alkanes, alkenes and alkynes

E81614EE43334A6BA6316600CCD32C3B.description: identify materials used in daily life that are based upon Alberta's petrochemical industry and that involve changes in energy; e.g., plastics, cosmetics, gasoline

135212D4EF264385871D291FDF06733A.description: Students will will describe the properties of simple hydrocarbons and describe hydrocarbon-based industrial processes that are important in Alberta.

57FC253F698D4F9A804882B48DFC394F.description: describe applications of science and technology that have developed in response to human and environmental needs

20792B248B1C4369988D3E6FBF4DB70A.description: illustrate how science and technology have influenced, and been influenced by, historical development and societal needs

0EC7D7F014EA492C980AA6801ABBC7C5.description: compare modern and traditional methods for the extraction of metals and for protection from corrosion; e.g., development of glazes in traditional Aboriginal pottery manufacturing.

F3A5C90348DF4D768541EB306A28A823.description: apply the principles of oxidation-reduction and half-reactions to describe, in general terms, the operation of voltaic and electrolytic cells; e.g., batteries, metal extraction, cathodic protection, galvanizing, electroplating

96E3B16DF4CA4518A6C1B65C0B94E1FE.description: define, operationally, oxidation and reduction and spontaneous and nonspontaneous reactions; i.e., loss of electrons is oxidation, gain of electrons is reduction, a spontaneous oxidation-reduction reaction produces electrical energy from chemical change, and a nonspontaneous oxidation-reduction reaction requires electrical energy to produce chemical change

68EB353FBCEE472B8AB5196EB7ADB140.description: relate single-replacement reactions to oxidation-reduction and apply mole ratios from given equations to predict moles of metals consumed or produced

BE1726BBB2544D2897FE2E063FBC9151.description: determine the reactivity of metals by comparing their reaction in various aqueous solutions

46505599E6EB4164A8F469C5BD81EA6D.description: balance provided single-replacement reaction equations, building on knowledge from Science 10, Unit A

7FFB4459D7FB4FB4949B657EAB42CE97.description: Students will explain oxidation, reduction and spontaneity and apply this knowledge to voltaic and electrolytic cells and to industrial processes.

36CAC7C573F9410D87E6817964BFCCD6.description: determine the concentration of diluted solutions and the quantities of a concentrated solution and of water to use when diluting.

42001C809444451694754F133D670599.description: determine the concentration of solutions in moles per litre, percent by volume and parts per million

0524ED7123114B9DA9B494BDF8EBBAC6.description: compare and explain how concentrations of solutions are expressed in moles per litre, percent by volume and parts per million

124E0B8A4948486EBF7752AD8F46DF9E.description: differentiate, on the basis of properties, between electrolytes and nonelectrolytes

AC65021B16D148C5AACB53D4DF9BBE2B.description: explain how dissolving substances in water is often a prerequisite for chemical reactions and chemical changes; e.g., batteries, baking, medications

9E3D555A0BD247E18B06ED5C66D55849.description: Students will investigate aqueous solutions to determine conductivity and to calculate concentration.
